text: Patient: Uh-uh. Doctor: And have you been able to-? Any of these things come out to you? Have you already seen these labs or everything I’m going to tell you is new? Patient: You going to tell me new. Doctor: Let me see what I have. You had your bloodwork yesterday. So your white count’s normal. Huh, you’re anemic, been about the same. You’ve got normal platelets. So your iron stuff isn’t really helping, but, huh, your kidney test, liver tests, your potassium is on the low side so you take your supplement. You probably often forget one of them, one of them probably, I bet. Doctor: It’s hard to remember that second one. Blood sugar’s okay. One of your bone tests is still high, but not as high as it was last time. That doesn’t mean we’re going to do anything different. But, huh, and then your liver tests, kidney tests are normal. Huh, your testosterone says you have no testosterone. So the medicines we’ve been giving you are doing their job. Then your PSA has changed. Huh, it was twenty three months ago, twenty-eight when I saw you four weeks ago, and now it’s thirty-nine. Let’s see what we have for scans. I’ll look at your brain. Your brain looks fine. Now to this MRI. Really they don’t talk much about your bones. That’s good. Huh, let’s see. Your bone scan. Huh, did we have that last time as well? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or in your case, you haven’t really been on a full dose, and you’ve had these interruptions where you’ve been, you know, totally off of it for three weeks, you know? And now for another two weeks. So. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: So when he comes back on September fifth, the two-hundred milligrams will be here, so he can take it with him that day? Doctor: Yes. That’s the plan. Provided that the hemoglobin is sufficient. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
